metadata.title: Alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas over Cu/ZnO catalysts: Effect of pH value in the co-precipitation step
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Fig. 5 NH3-TPD profiles of selected Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. Fig. 6 Catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis at 150°C and 50bar with time on stream. Fig. 7 XRD patterns of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst before and after the catalytic reactions. Table 1 Specific surface area, chemical composition, and crystallite size of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts prepared at different pH values (X). Catalyst Specific surface area a (m2/g) Cu/Zn b Crystallite size (nm) c ZnO (101) Cu (111) Cu/ZnO_6 26.4 1.02 14.0 12.5 Cu/ZnO_7 22.8 0.96 14.9 13.1 Cu/ZnO_8 23.3 1.01 15.7 11.7 Cu/ZnO_9 31.1 0.99 14.9 12.5 Cu/ZnO_10 20.8 0.97 17.2 25.4 a Specific surface area was determined by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) plot. b Atomic ratio of Cu/Zn was determined by ICP-AES analysis. c Crystallite size was calculated by the scherrer equation. Table 2 Acid properties of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts prepared at different pH values (X). Catalyst Acidity (mmolNH3/gcat) Weak acid site(140–180°C) Medium acid site(200–240°C) Strong acid site(310–340°C) Total acidity Cu/ZnO_6 0.08 0.21 0.30 0.59 Cu/ZnO_7 0.07 0.15 0.32 0.54 Cu/ZnO_8 0.08 0.14 0.42 0.64 Cu/ZnO_9 0.10 0.22 0.37 0.69 Cu/ZnO_10 0.12 0.41 0.14 0.67 Alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas over Cu/ZnO catalysts: Effect of pH value in the co-precipitation step Yeojin Jeong a Ilho Kim a Ji Yeon Kang a Heondo Jeong b Jong Ki Park b Jong Ho Park b ⁎ Ji Chul Jung a ⁎⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, Myongji University, 116 Myongji-ro, Cheoin-gu, Yongin 449-728, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical Engineering Myongji University 116 Myongji-ro Cheoin-gu Yongin 449-728 Republic of Korea b Korea Institute of Energy Research, 152 Gajeong-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 305-343, Republic of Korea Korea Institute of Energy Research 152 Gajeong-ro Yuseong-gu Daejeon 305-343 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 42 860 3249; fax: +82 42 860 3133. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 31 330 6390; fax: +82 31 337 1920. Graphical abstract Alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas was conducted in a batch type reactor using ethanol as both a solvent and a reaction intermediate. Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method with different co-precipitation pH values (X =6–10), with an aim of investigating the effect of pH value on the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in this reaction. The co-precipitation pH value had a strong influence on the Cu crystallite size, the surface morphology, and the surface acidity, leading to the different activities of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts depending on the pH value (X). Catalyst characterization and reaction mechanism clearly revealed that Cu crystallite size and strong acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts played key roles in determining their catalytic activity in this reaction. Yield for methanol showed a tendency to increase with decreasing Cu crystallite size and with increasing strong acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. Among Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst prepared at pH 8 showed the best catalytic performance due to the finely dispersed Cu particles and the high strong acidity. In addition, the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst maintained at the same level even after a 60h-catalytic reaction, leading to the high feasibility of application of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst to the continuous reaction system along with the batch reaction system for methanol production from syngas. Keywords Methanol synthesis Alcohol-assisted Low temperature Cu/ZnO Effect of pH 1 Introduction Methanol is the simplest alcohol with the chemical formula of CH3OH. It is also called a platform chemical, because it can be converted to the various fuels and the invaluable chemicals [1–5]. Gasoline can be produced by the methanol to gasoline process, which was developed by Mobile in the early 1970s. In addition, a large amount of methanol has been used to produce methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) as a gasoline additive. Methanol to olefins (MTO) process may also require considerable amounts of methanol in the future to produce ethylene and propylene [6–8]. However, the current major market of methanol is in synthesizing various important chemicals such as formaldehyde, dimethyl ether, and acetic acid. Therefore, it is generally expected that these various applications of methanol will be continuously expanding its market [9–11]. Methanol is currently produced by the catalytic industrial process (ICI process) from syngas, which is a mixture of hydrogen, carbon dioxide, and carbon monoxide. Cu/ZnO–Al2O3 is well known to be an efficient catalyst with a high selectivity for this catalytic process [2–4]. In other words, methanol is conventionally produced by copper based catalysts according to the following reaction. CO+2H2 →CH3OH (g), ΔH 298 =−90.97kJ/mol However, the limitation of thermodynamic in this reaction results in a high cost of methanol production. This catalytic process operates at high temperature (250–300°C) and high pressure (50–100bar). The conflict between the highly exothermic reaction and the high reaction temperature lead to a low one-pass conversion in this reaction. Accordingly, the unreacted reactants should be recycled, and thus, the efficiency of this catalytic process is severely limited [12–17]. To overcome these problems, a low temperature methanol synthesis (LTMS) process has been firstly proposed by the Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL). The BNL introduced a low temperature methanol synthesis process using a strong base catalyst, which is composed of a mixture of NaH, alcohol, and Me(Ac)2. However, the strong base catalyst was quickly deactivated by the trace amount of carbon dioxide and water in the syngas [18–23]. Christiansen also proposed a low temperature methanol synthesis process operated around 100°C using a catalytic process via methyl formate. According to the reported mechanism, an alkyl formate is synthesized by the carbonylation of alcohol, and subsequently, the catalytic hydrogenolysis of alkyl formate produces methanol and the starting alcohol [24]. This catalytic process also requires a homogeneous alkali metal methoxide catalyst for the carbonylation reaction, where carbon dioxide and water in the syngas deactivate the alkali metal methoxide catalyst. Therefore, pure carbon monoxide and hydrogen in the feed, which can be obtained from the complete removal of carbon dioxide and water from syngas, are absolutely required to commercialize the catalytic LTMS processes proposed by BNL and Christiansen group. In the end, this additional process for the separation of feedstock makes the commercialization of LTMS process impossible due to its high cost [25,26]. For an alternative to the above LTMS processes, Tsubaki and co-workers suggested a new alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis process using a liquid phase reaction, where carbon dioxide and water are utilized as reaction intermediates. In addition, this new route can be operated at significantly low temperature (150–170°C) and low pressure (30–50bar). Therefore, it is believed that methanol can be commercially produced by this catalytic LTMS process without any purification of syngas [27–29], and thus, developing an efficient catalyst for this reaction would be worthwhile. Cu/ZnO catalyst has been considered as an efficient catalyst for the alcohol-assisted LTMS process proposed by Tsubaki and co-workers [27,28]. Co-precipitation method has been generally utilized for the preparation of Cu/ZnO catalyst [30–33]. It has been reported that various preparation conditions such as identity of precursor, co-precipitation pH value, and co-precipitation temperature can strongly affect the surface property and the activity of the catalyst prepared by a co-precipitation [34,35]. In particular, pH value in the co-precipitation step is known to be a key factor for the successful design of Cu/ZnO catalyst. However, any systematic investigation to see the effect of pH value in the preparation of Cu/ZnO on the catalytic activity in the alcohol-assisted LTMS was not attempted yet. In this work, a series of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method with a variation of pH value (X =6–10), and they were applied to the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas containing carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and hydrogen. We attempted to clarify the effect of pH value in the co-precipitation step on the catalytic property and activity of Cu/ZnO_X using various characterization tools such as XRD, TEM, SEM, and NH3-TPD analyses. Finally, correlations between catalytic properties and activities of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A series of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were prepared by a conventional co-precipitation method with a variation of pH value (X) in the co-precipitation step. Copper nitrate (Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O, Sigma–Aldrich) and zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2∙6H2O, Sigma–Aldrich) were employed as metal precursors, and sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, Kanto Chemical Co.) was used as a precipitation agent. Atomic ratio of Cu/Zn was fixed at 1 in all Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. The detail procedures for the preparation of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were as follows. 24.2g of copper nitrate was dissolved in distilled water (solution A). 29.8g of zinc nitrate was separately dissolved in distilled water (solution B). The solution A and the solution B were added dropwise into 600ml of distilled water at 70°C under vigorous stirring. During the co-precipitation step, the pH value was varied from 6 to 10 with an interval of 1 using a 1.5M Na2CO3 aqueous solution. The resulting solution was vigorously stirred at 70°C for 1h, and then, it was filtered to obtain a solid product. The obtained product was thoroughly washed with distilled water to remove sodium ion, and subsequently, it was dried overnight at 120°C. After the dried sample was calcined at 350°C for 1h with an air stream, it was reduced in a mixed stream of hydrogen and nitrogen. Finally, the passivation was conducted in a stream of 1% oxygen diluted by argon at room temperature for 1h, with an aim of preventing the rapid oxidation of metallic copper into copper oxide by excessive oxygen in air. The prepared catalysts were denoted as Cu/ZnO_X, where X represents the pH value in the co-precipitation step. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Crystalline phase of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts prepared at different pH values was examined by XRD measurements (X’pert-pro, PANalytical) using Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.54056Å). XRD patterns were recorded from 2θ =10° to 80° at 40kV and 40mA. Copper dispersion and particle size in the catalysts were examined by TEM (JEM-2100F, JEOL) analysis. Atomic ratio of Cu/Zn in the catalysts was determined by ICP-AES (Prodigy, Teledyne Leeman Labs) analysis. SEM analysis (Jeol, JSM-6700F) was carried out to investigate the surface morphology of the catalysts. Surface area of the catalysts was analyzed by N2 adsorption–desorption measurements using a BELSORP-mini II (BEL Japan). Acid properties of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were determined by ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) method. NH3-TPD experiments were performed with a conventional TPD instrument (Autocohem II 2920, Micromeritics). Each catalyst (ca. 0.1g) was charged into the quartz reactor of conventional TPD apparatus. Prior to the TPD experiments, the adsorbed organic impurities on the surface of the catalyst were removed at 200°C for 1h under a flow of helium. NH3 was then adsorbed on the acid sites of the catalyst at 100°C, and subsequently, the physisorbed NH3 was removed by evacuating the sample at 50°C for 1h. The experiments were carried out in the temperature range of 30–600°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. The desorbed NH3 was detected using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Reaction procedure Alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas was performed in a stainless steel autoclave reactor with an inner volume of 180ml. A typical reaction procedure was as follows. 50ml of ethanol and 3g of catalyst were loaded in the autoclave reactor. After purging the reactor with carbon dioxide, the reactor was pressurized to 36bar with the feed gas (CO:CO2:H2 =30:5:65). The reactor was then heated to the reaction temperature (150°C). When the temperature of reactor reached 150°C, the catalytic reaction was started with vigorous stirring. The catalytic reaction was carried out at 50bar for 20h. After the reaction was completed, the reactor was cooled to room temperature by cooling water, and the liquid products were collected for analysis. Quantitative and qualitative analyses of the liquid products were performed by a gas chromatograph (YL-6500, Yonglin) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). 2-Propanol was used as an internal standard to quantify the products. The reaction products were separated using a HP-PLOT Q column (30m×0.53mm I.D., 40μm film thickness). Product selectivity and yield were calculated by the following equations. Selectivity for A ( % ) = moles of A formed total moles of products formed × 100 Yield for A ( % ) = moles of A formed moles of CO and C O 2 ⁡ supplied × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Successful formation of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was well confirmed by XRD measurements. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts prepared at different co-precipitation pH values. The crystalline phases observed in the catalysts were identified by the joint committee on powder diffraction standards (JCPDS) files. All Cu/ZnO_X catalysts exhibited well crystallized patterns. The main diffraction patterns of 2θ at 36.3° and 43.2° were the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZnO (101) and Cu (111) phases, respectively. Therefore, it is thought that metallic copper and zinc oxide were well developed in all catalysts, indicating that we successfully prepared Cu/ZnO_X catalysts by a co-precipitation in this work. Interestingly, XRD peak breadth was much different depending on the pH value in the co-precipitation step. This means that the crystallite size of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was strongly affected by the co-precipitation pH value. In order to confirm the effect of pH value on the crystallite size of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, the crystallite sizes of Cu and ZnO were calculated by the strongest peaks of Cu (111) (2θ =43.2°) and ZnO (101) (2θ =36.3°), respectively, using the Scherrer equation: D = Kλ/βcosθ, where K was the Scherrer constant, λ was the wavelength of X-ray, and D denotes the mean crystallite size. As expected, the pH value in the co-precipitation step had a strong influence on the crystallite size of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts (Table 1 ). In particular, the crystallite size of ZnO was not greatly affected by the co-precipitation pH value, while the crystallize size of Cu was closely related to the co-precipitation pH value. Among the Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, Cu/ZnO_8 retained the smallest crystallite size of Cu (ca. 11.7nm). Many researchers agree with that metallic copper is a main active site in the catalytic methanol synthesis from syngas. Therefore, it is inferred that the co-precipitation pH value in the preparation of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts can be one of the crucial factors to determine the crystallite size of Cu, and accordingly, to affect the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in this reaction. It is expected that Cu/ZnO catalyst with a small crystallite size of Cu will show an excellent catalytic performance in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas. Additionally, it is worthwhile to note that only Cu/ZnO_10 catalyst prepared at pH 10 showed a minor XRD peak at 2θ =38.8°. This XRD peak is attributed to the diffraction pattern of CuO, indicating that metallic copper could be easily oxidized to copper oxide during the catalyst preparation process due to the large Cu crystallite size of Cu/ZnO_10 catalyst. Therefore, it is thought that Cu/ZnO_10 may exhibit a poor catalytic activity in this reaction. TEM analysis was also conducted with an aim of confirming the copper dispersion and the particle size in Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, the obtained figures were shown in Fig. 2 . As expected, Cu/ZnO_10 prepared at pH 10 retained a much higher copper particle size than the others, which is good agreement with the XRD results. In addition, the copper particle sizes of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts determined by TEM images showed a similar trend with those calculated by the Scherrer equation. Once again, we confirmed that the pH value in the co-precipitation step can strongly affect the copper particle sizes of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, and thus, their catalytic activity in this reaction. Chemical composition of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts prepared at different pH values was determined by ICP-AES analyses, and the corresponding results are listed in Table 1. Atomic ratios of Cu/Zn were found to be ca. 1 in all Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, and these values was well consistent with the designed values. This result strongly supports that all Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were successfully prepared by a co-precipitation in this work. Specific surface areas of Cu/ZnO catalysts calculated by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) plot were found to be in the range of 20.8–31.1m2/g (Table 1). However, any correlation between the specific surface area and the co-precipitation pH value was not shown. Surface morphology of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was observed by SEM analyses. It is interesting that platelike structure was observed in only Cu/ZnO_7 and Cu/ZnO_8 catalysts, while Cu/ZnO_6, Cu/ZnO_9, and Cu/ZnO_10 retained a three dimensional random network structure of catalyst particles (Fig. 3 ). Therefore, it is believed that the surface morphology of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was also strongly affected by the co-precipitation pH value, leading to their different catalytic performance in this reaction. 3.2 Catalytic performance in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis Catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts prepared at different pH values was investigated by conducting the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis at 150°C for 20h (Fig. 4 ). It is well known that methyl acetate and ethyl formate are formed as main by-products in this reaction. However, the amount of ethyl formate produced in this work was negligible, and thus, its quantitative analysis was not included in the calculation of selectivity and yield. In addition, it is interesting to note that ethyl acetate was also produced as a by-product. It is reported that ethyl acetate can be produced by the catalytic ethanol dehydrogenation over Cu/ZnO catalyst [36]. Therefore, it is believed that ethyl acetate was originated from ethanol, which was employed as both a solvent and a reaction intermediate in this reaction. As shown in Fig. 4, selectivity for products (methanol and methyl acetate) was almost constant (methanol: ca. 94.3% and methyl acetate: ca. 5.7%) except for Cu/ZnO_10 catalyst, while yield for methanol exhibited a volcano-shaped curve with respect to co-precipitation pH value. Therefore, it can be inferred that the difference in methanol yield depending on the co-precipitation, pH value was obtained from the different conversion of carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide in this reaction. As expected, the maximum yield was obtained over Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst. In particular, Cu/ZnO_10 catalyst showed a low methanol selectivity of 70% and a high selectivity of methyl acetate of 30% compared to the other catalysts. When considering the fact that metallic copper is well known as a main active site in this reaction, the enhanced catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_8 was due to its small Cu crystallite size by the high dispersion of metallic copper. Moreover, it is thought that the platelike structure of Cu/ZnO_7 and Cu/ZnO_8 catalysts was partially responsible for their high catalytic performance. In order to clarify the effect of Cu crystallite size on the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in this reaction, a correlation between Cu crystallite size of Cu/ZnO_X catalyst and methanol yield was investigated. Although the correlation plot was not shown here, the methanol yield was increased with decreasing Cu crystallite size, and accordingly, with increasing Cu surface area. Among Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst with the smallest Cu crystallite size showed the highest yield for methanol in this reaction (Fig. 4 and Table 1). This indicates that Cu crystallite size was one of the crucial factors to determine the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas. 3.3 Acid property of Cu/ZnO catalyst As mentioned above, alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis (LTMS), where alcohol was used as both a solvent and a reaction intermediate, was firstly proposed by Tsubaki and co-workers in 2001 [27,28]. According to the proposed reaction pathway, the alcohol-assisted LTMS reaction over Cu/ZnO catalyst consists of five sequential reaction steps as follows. (1) CO+H2O→CO2 +H2 (2) CO2 +1/2H2 +Cu→HCOOCu (3) HCOOCu+ROH→HCOOR+CuOH (4) HCOOR+2H2 →ROH+CH3OH (5) CuOH+1/2H2 →H2O+Cu Net: CO+2H2 →CH3OH Especially, esterification reaction (step (3)) is known to be the rate-determining step, and this reaction step can proceed with acid catalyst in mild condition [27]. It was also reported that metallic copper can easily catalyze the reaction steps of (1), (2), (4), and (5) [27,28]. From these results, it can be deduced that not only the Cu crystallite size but also the acid property of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts may play significant roles in determining the catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis. NH3-TPD experiments were conducted to determine the acid properties of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, with an aim of investigating the effect of acid property on the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in this reaction. Fig. 5 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of selected Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. Peak deconvolution reveals that all Cu/ZnO_X catalysts retained three types of acid sites, and the corresponding results are summarized in Table 2 . The weak, the medium, and the strong acid sites corresponds to the NH3-TPD peaks observed in the temperature range of 140–180°C, 200–240°C, and 310–340°C, respectively. Interestingly, it was found that the peak temperatures were almost constant regardless of the co-precipitation pH value, while the peak areas were much different depending on the co-precipitation pH value. It is clear that the co-precipitation pH value (X) has a strong influence on the acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. However, it was found that the weak acidity, the medium, and the total acidity showed no reliable correlation with the co-precipitation pH value and the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. In particular, the peak area in the temperature range of 310–340°C, which was originated from the strong acid sites of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, was clearly affected by the co-precipitation pH value. In other words, a reliable correlation between the strong acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts and the methanol yield over Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was obtained. Methanol yield over Cu/ZnO_X catalysts exhibited a tendency to increase with increasing strong acid site of the catalyst (Fig. 4 and Table 2). Among the catalyst tested in this work, Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst retained the highest strong acid sites, leading to its highest methanol yield in this reaction. This implies that the strong acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts played a key role in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis. Therefore, the research on the increment of strong acidity of copper based catalyst for this reaction is currently underway through the modification of support. 3.4 Effect of reaction time Effect of reaction time on the catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was investigated by carrying out the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis for various reaction times. For this purpose, Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst was chosen as a model catalyst. As shown in the catalytic performance of Cu/ZnO_8 with time on stream (Fig. 6 ), methanol yield was monotonically increased with increasing reaction time. Interestingly, the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_8 catalysts maintained at the same level even after a 60h-catalytic reaction. Selectivity for methyl acetate was slowly decreased with time on stream. As mentioned earlier, carbon dioxide and water in the syngas should be removed in the conventional low temperature methanol synthesis to avoid the catalyst deactivation. In contrast with the conventional low temperature methanol synthesis, however, we attempted to use ethanol as both a solvent and a reaction intermediate so that we could directly utilize carbon dioxide and water in the syngas as reaction intermediate without any additional separation process. Therefore, it is noteworthy that no deactivation of Cu/ZnO_8 was observed, despite the existence of carbon dioxide in the reaction feed. This means a high feasibility of application of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst to the continuous reaction system along with the batch reaction system for methanol production from syngas. Structure stability of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst during the catalytic reaction was also confirmed by investigating its XRD patterns after a catalytic reaction. For the XRD measurements, the Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst was recovered after a 20h- and a 60h-catalytic reaction. Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst exhibited no difference in XRD patterns before and after the catalytic reaction for 60h (Fig. 7 ). Once again, we confirmed that Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst was stable during the catalytic reaction, and thus, served as an efficient catalyst in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis. 4 Conclusion A series of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method with a variation of pH value (X =6–10), and they were applied to the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas. In contrast with the conventional low temperature methanol synthesis, ethanol was employed as both a solvent and a reaction intermediate in this reaction. Successful formation of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was well confirmed by XRD and ICP-AES analyses. Yield for methanol over Cu/ZnO_X catalyst showed a volcano-shaped curve with respect to pH value in the co-precipitation step. The maximum methanol yield was obtained over Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst prepared at pH 8. The catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts was closely related to their Cu crystallite size and strong acidity. Low Cu crystallite size and high strong acidity were favorable for the methanol production from syngas over Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst prepared at pH 8 retained the lowest Cu crystallite size and the highest strong acidity, and at the same time, the best catalytic performance in this reaction. Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst showed a stable catalytic activity without deactivation for 60h, and its crystalline structure also exhibited no change between before and after the catalytic reaction. Consequently, Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst served as an efficient catalyst in the alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis. coredata.dc:description: Alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas was conducted in a batch type reactor using ethanol as both a solvent and a reaction intermediate. Cu/ZnO_X catalysts were prepared by a co-precipitation method with different co-precipitation pH values (X =6–10), with an aim of investigating the effect of pH value on the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts in this reaction. The co-precipitation pH value had a strong influence on the Cu crystallite size, the surface morphology, and the surface acidity, leading to the different activities of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts depending on the pH value (X). Catalyst characterization and reaction mechanism clearly revealed that Cu crystallite size and strong acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts played key roles in determining their catalytic activity in this reaction. Yield for methanol showed a tendency to increase with decreasing Cu crystallite size and with increasing strong acidity of Cu/ZnO_X catalysts. Among Cu/ZnO_X catalysts, Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst prepared at pH 8 showed the best catalytic performance due to the finely dispersed Cu particles and the high strong acidity. In addition, the catalytic activity of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst maintained at the same level even after a 60h-catalytic reaction, leading to the high feasibility of application of Cu/ZnO_8 catalyst to the continuous reaction system along with the batch reaction system for methanol production from syngas.
coredata.dc:title: Alcohol-assisted low temperature methanol synthesis from syngas over Cu/ZnO catalysts: Effect of pH value in the co-precipitation step
